headline: RIL's gas production from KG-D6 fields below 34 mmscmd/day
description: Reliance Industries has reported natural gas production from its eastern offshore KG-D6 fields dropping to less than 34 million standard cubic meters a day.
tags: Business, KG-D6, natural gas production, oil and gas, oil ministry, Reliance Industries, RIL
articleBody: Reliance Industries has reported natural gas production from its eastern offshore KG-D6 fields dropping to less than 34 million standard cubic meters a day. Gas output from KG-D6 in the week ended April 1 dropped to 33.89 mmscmd from 34.09 mmscmd in the previous week, according to a status report filed by the company with the Oil Ministry. KG-D6, where water and sand ingress coupled with drop in pressure has led a drastic fall in per-well output, had produced 34.62 mmscmd in the begging of March. Production from Dhirubhai-1 and 3, the largest among the 19 oil and gas finds RIL has made in the KG-DWN-98/3 or KG-D6 block, slipped to 27.52 mmscmd during March 26 and April 1. The twin fields had produced 27.64 mmscmd during March 19-25 and 28.16 mmscmd in the week ending March 4. Together with 6.37 mmscmd output from MA oilfield in the same block, KG-D6 produced 33.89 mmsmcd during the week ending April 1. The KG-D6 output has fallen since hitting peak of 61.5 mmscmd in March 2010 as RIL shut wells after wells on water and sand ingress. During the week under review, &quot;total 12 wells were on production and 6 wells (A2, A6, A10, B1, B2 &amp;amp; B13) were kept closed due to high water cut/sanding issues,&quot; the report said. The output from KG-D6 is short of the 70.39 mmscmd-level (61.88 mmscmd from D1 and D3 and 8.5 mmscmd from the MA field) envisaged by now as per the field development plan approved in 2006. While Reliance holds 60% interest in KG-D6, UK's BP Plc holds 30% and Niko Resources of Canada the remaining 10%. The report said one out of the six well on MA field had to be shut due to water loading. The field produced an average of 11,071 barrels per day of oil in the week and 1,627 barrels per day of condensate. Of the 33.89 mmscmd of production, 12.71 mmscmd was sold to fertiliser plants at government approved rate of USD 4.20 per million British thermal unit. Another 18.10 mmscmd was sold to power plants and the remaining 3.08 mmscmd was consumed sectors such as LPG. RIL projected an output of 33.7 mmscmd during the month.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Essar Oil sees margins jump after expansion
description: A major upgrading of its refinery in Gujarat by Essar Oil should boost its margins by up to USD 5 a barrel, adding nearly three quarters of a billion dollars to its annual revenues.
tags: Business, crude, Essar Oil, Vadinar refinery
articleBody: A major upgrading of its refinery in Gujarat by Essar Oil should boost its margins by up to USD 5 a barrel, its chief executive said on Thursday, adding nearly three quarters of a billion dollars to its annual revenues. Essar has just completed a USD 1.6 billion overhaul and expansion at the Vadinar refinery, raising capacity to around 360,000 barrels per day from 280,000 bpd and adding units that can process cheaper, heavier crude into fuels. The refinery would reach 400,000 bpd capacity in September, Managing Director Lalit Kumar Gupta said. &quot;The difference in our margins and those in our neighbouring refinery, which is as complex as we are today, has been about USD 3 to USD 4/bbl. We should be able to bridge that gap now,&quot; Gupta told Reuters in an interview. The refinery would gain another USD 1 a barrel in margins through using a coal-fired power plant to provide electricity, which would save on fuel costs, Gupta said. Essar had earlier forecast a 35% jump in revenues for the fiscal year that started on April 1. Revenues for the previous fiscal year were around &amp;#36;9.5 billion. Essar plans to sell a stake of around 15% by June 2013, as required by the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) to reduce the stake held by founding shareholders to 75% from nearly 90% now. The company believes its shares are trading below value and the price will improve after investors see it operate the newly expanded refinery for two quarters, Gupta said. That would be a better time for any stake sale, he added. Given the full expansion will be completed in September, that would push any possible stake-sell to close to the deadline. &quot;We will come to market when we are rightly priced. At the current price we think we are heavily undervalued. We see significant upside in our refinery business,&quot; Gupta said. Essar Oil's market valuation stands at USD 1.3 billion and its shares have barely changed so far in 2012, closing on Thursday at Rs 50 a share, a fraction of the peak in 2008 of nearly Rs 356. Essar, 87% owned by London-listed Essar Energy , is one of only two private refiners in India. The other is Reliance Industries, which operates the world's biggest refining complex at Jamnagar and has among the best margins in the industry. Reliance reported gross refining margins of USD 7.60 a barrel for the March quarter, down from USD 9.20 a year ago. Margins Gupta said he expected refinery margins to rise in coming quarters as the northern hemisphere summer driving season demand kicked in and improved profits for making gasoline. &quot;Going forward, once the gasoline cracks are better, margins can only go up,&quot; he said. &quot;Definitely complex refineries have to make more margins.&quot; The company is currently negotiating with the government in Gujarat more time to repay a USD 1.24 billion sales tax due after the Supreme Court dismissed Essar's petition seeking a review of an earlier verdict to defer payment. Essar, which has already booked a Rs 4000&amp;nbsp;crore loss in its books for the tax liability, hopes to service repayments from the increased cashflows of its expanded refinery, but is also in talks with several banks to raise funds for the payment, Gupta said, but declined to name the banks. &quot;If the Gujarat government insists on some interest, to that extent our earnings will definitely get impacted. But going forward, we see strong cash flows and earnings, so we are not unduly worried,&quot; Gupta said. Essar will be able to use heavy crude for almost 80% of its capacity and is gradually shifting to Latin American oil from Venezuela, Colombia, Mexico and Brazil. &quot;Middle East crude slowly will get reduced in our basket. If they are not low API, if they are costlier, we will reduce. Ultimately, it's a question of optimising margins,&quot; Gupta said. Essar is also reducing dependence on oil from Iran, its single largest supplier, in line with plans by other Indian refiners as international sanctions target the flow of Iran's exports. The US and its allies aim to reduce Iran's oil revenues to pressure Tehran not to build nuclear weapons. Essar had renewed a contract with Iran in January for 100,000 bpd, Gupta said, the same volume as last year. Iranian crude would account for around 25% of Essar's supplies when the expansion was completed, down from around 40 percent, he added. Industry sources have told Reuters Essar plans to cut 15% from its 100,0000 bpd contract, which runs from April 2012 for a year. Gupta declined to comment. Earlier this month, data published by a leading industry consultant showed India has vaulted to the top of the list of Iran's oil customers, overtaking China, in a first-quarter buying surge ahead of tighter sanctions against Tehran this summer. India's Iranian crude imports could fall around 25% from April, when new annual contracts take effect.

headline: Reduce Ambuja Cement, buy Hindustan Zinc, hold RIL: Emkay
description: Emkay Global Financial Services has recommended to reduce Ambuja Cement, buy Hindustan Zinc and hold Reliance Industries (RIL) for targets of Rs 165, Rs 147 and Rs 835 respectievely, in its April 20, 2012 research report.
tags: Ambuja Cement, Emkay Global Financial Services, Hindustan Zinc, recommendation, Recommendations, Reliance Industries, RIL
articleBody: Emkay Global Financial Services has recommended to reduce Ambuja Cements, buy Hindustan Zinc and hold Reliance Industries (RIL) for targets of Rs 165, Rs 147 and Rs 835 respectievely, in its April 20, 2012 research report. Ambuja Cements: Plans to increase its capacity with brownfield expansion at Sankrail grinding unit in the eastern region adding 0.8mtpa capacity and a Greenfield expansion project to set up 2.2mtpa clinkerization unit in Nagaur district (agreement signed with Rajastan Industrial Development and Industrial Corporation in 2010). The Rajasthan plant is expected to come on stream by 2015. The company also plans to start production of coal for the coal block allotted in the state of Maharashtra (in a JV with IST and Lafarge) by 2015. The total capex for these projects is estimated to be at Rs27bn. The funding for the project would be through internal accruals as Ambuja’s cash and cash equivalents for CY11 itself stood at Rs 29bn. Though Ambuja’s 1QCY12 performance was boosted by lower costs helping expansion in margins, we expect margins to come under pressure in the ensuing quarters as the recent cost increases like railway freight hike (+23% effective from March 6, 2012) &amp;amp; excise duty hike (+200 bps increased on March 16, 2012)) are yet to reflect completely. CIL’s coal price hikes post its wage hike would also add further pressure on energy costs. Revenues at Rs26.3bn grew 19.3% yoy as cement volumes grew 9.6% yoy while realizations at Rs4262/t grew 8.9% yoy and 4.3% qoq. We believe that the stock’s valuations at 8.3X EV/E &amp;amp; EV/T of USD163 does not factor in these margin risks and leaves little upside from current levels. Maintain Reduce. Hindustan Zinc: During FY12 annual production capacity of lead was enhanced to 193kt (from 93ktpa, silver capacity enhanced to 500tpa (from 250ktpa), while a zinc smelter of 60ktpa (from total capacity of 879ktpa) brought under ramp down. The mining plan of their mine (largest mine namely Agucha) warrant development activities during H1FY12 at the site which could adversely affect production before it restarts at full rate during H2FY12. The lead business would ramp up steadily during FY13. We expect silver business to grow slowly clocking 300 ton in FY13 and 350 ton in FY14 (Co has however guided 350ton in FY13).  Focus currently lies on systematic greenfield exploration opportunities over 4500 sq km of area on which they have Reconnaisance Permits (RPs). It has also sought new RPs for around 18700 sq km. It is quite evident that additional refined metal capacities will be taken up only after they have access to fresh mining sources. With the strong balance sheet and cash of Rs180bn as on 31st March 2012 possibility of growth through acquisition cannot be ruled out. They have also announced dividend policy envisaging about 20% PAT as dividend payout. At the CMP of Rs 126, the stock is trading at 8.2x its FY14E EPS and 3.8x FY14E EV/ EBITDA. We value the stock at 5x FY14 EV/ EBITDA. Maintain Buy with a revised target price of Rs 147/ share. Reliance Industries (RIL): Reported its numbers above our expectations and in line with market expectations. GRMs surprised on upside with higher margins QoQ despite benchmark Singapore GRMs being lower QoQ and light-heavy crude spread worsening. Company reported GRM of &amp;#36;7.6/bbl v/s &amp;#36;6.8 in Q3FY12 and &amp;#36;9.2/bbl Q4FY11. Higher Other Income at Rs23bn v/s Rs9bn in Q4FY11 stalled the decline of net profit to Rs42bn, a decline of 21%yoy and 5%qoq. Going ahead we remain cautious on refining and petchem margins on the back of weak demand and/or new capacities additions. While the concerns on declining gas production in KG basin have remained, RIL stock has under performed by 12% / 20% in the last 3months/12months. Also a weak refining and petchem margin scenario has not helped the stock. Going ahead we see refining segment on a weak footing on the back of weak demand. Refining margins may gain some support from refining mothballing in US and Europe, however we suspect the sustainability of such support. As of now about 2mbpd of refining capacity in US and Europe is either shut down and looking for buyer or operating at lower capacity. (Refer our Oil &amp;amp; Gas update dated 18th April 2012). In case of petchem, demand remains a concern and any weakness in demand could impact any sustained recovery in margins. With the likelihood of gas production declining further, the stock is likely to remain weak and underperform going ahead. Going ahead we remain cautious on refining and petchem margins on the back of new capacities and/or weakening demand. We now factor in lower GRMs and built in flat margins from petchem for FY13E and FY14E. The stock currently trades at FY13E and FY14E PE multiple of 11.7x and 11.2x, we maintain our reco to Hold and cut our target price to Rs835 (Rs.879 earlier), says Emkay Global Financial Services research report. Shares held by Central Governments/State Governments  Disclaimer: The views and investment tips expressed by investment experts/broking houses/rating agencies on moneycontrol.com are their own, and not that of the website or its management. headline: Accumulate Reliance Industries; target of Rs 800: KRChoksey
description: KRChoksey is bullish on Reliance Industries and has recommended accumulate rating on the stock with a target of Rs 800 in its April 23, 2012 research report.
articleBody: KRChoksey is bullish on Reliance Industries and has recommended accumulate rating on the stock with a target of Rs 800 in its April 23, 2012 research report. “Reliance Industries Ltd (RIL) reported net Profit of Rs 4236 cr, in line with our expectation (Rs 4210 cr). Net profit declined by 21% y-o-y, mainly due to the company not able to arrest falling gas production from KG-D6, reduction in deltas across olefins and polyester chain. Net sales improved by 17% to Rs 85,182 cr on Yo- Y largely due to higher prices of products while increase in volume accounted only 2%. Other income was higher at Rs 2295 cr as against Rs 917 cr on a y-o-y basis primarily due to higher average liquid investments. Outstanding debt at the end of Q4FY12 was Rs 65,352 cr compared to Rs 66,236 cr as on 31st March 2011.”  “36% Dip in revenue on Y-o-Y basis and ~8% on Q-o- Q basis to Rs 2609 cr mainly due to fall in production to the level of 36 mmscmd (AvgQ4FY12) and transfer of 30% Participating Interest (PI) in KG-D6 to BP. RIL has identified satellite and cluster fields, which can be developed and connected to production facilities, to increase gas volumes. RIL, along with BP has suggested to the government integrated field development plan to reduce costs and increase gas production. The company hopes to submit integrated FDP by Dec-12, and hopes to bring the whole field into production in next three years. RIL provided positive commentary on E&amp;amp;P portfolio and BP’s technical expertise is expected to help arrest decline in gas production and eventually increase from current levels.”  “We believe that refining margin improving but still relatively low we expect pickup in regional margins in 2H CY12. Any gradual recovery in downstream demand and improvement in global operating rates would be positive trigger for petchem and We are more positive on upstream (revision of gas price and pick up in shale gas) key trigger would be greater visibility on non-D6 production. we recommend Accumulate on RIL with price objective of Rs 800/share,” says KRChoksey research report.&amp;nbsp;  Institutional holding more than 40% in Indian cos  Disclaimer: The views and investment tips expressed by investment experts/broking houses/rating agencies on moneycontrol.com are their own, and not that of the website or its management. headline: Buy Reliance Industries; target of Rs 872: Angel Broking
description: Angel Broking is bullish on Reliance Industries and has recommended buy rating on the stock with a target of Rs 872 in its April 20, 2012 research report.
tags: Angel Broking, recommendation, Recommendations, Reliance Industries
articleBody: Angel Broking is bullish on Reliance Industries and has recommended buy rating on the stock with a target of Rs 872 in its April 20, 2012 research report. “For 4QFY2012, Reliance Industries (RIL) reported 17.2% yoy growth in its top line. However, EBITDA and PAT declined by 33.3% yoy and 21.2% yoy, respectively, due to a decline in KG-D6 gas production and lower gross refining margins (GRMs).”  “RIL’s net sales increased by 17.2% yoy to Rs 85,182cr, in-line with our estimate of Rs 84,669cr. However, EBITDA decreased by 33.3% yoy to Rs 6,563cr on account of lower profits from all its three main segments. GRM stood at US&amp;#36;7.6/bbl in 4QFY2012 compared to US&amp;#36;9.2/bbl in 4QFY2011 and US&amp;#36;6.8/bbl in 3QFY2012. Production from KG-D6 stood at 35mmscmd in 4QFY2012 compared to 41mmscmd in 3QFY2012 and 51mmscmd in 4QFY2011. Other income increased by 150.3% yoy to Rs 2,295cr and depreciation expenses decreased by 21.5% yoy to Rs 2,659cr. Hence, despite the 33.3% decline in EBITDA, PAT decreased by only 21.2% yoy to Rs 4,236cr (slightly above our estimate of Rs 4,177cr).”  “During 4QFY2012, RIL finalized its plan to set up a petcoke gasification plant for a capex of US&amp;#36;4bn. The company also downgraded its KG-D6 reserves by 12-15% due to reservoir complexity. RIL’s refining and petrochemical segments’ profits declined during 4QFY2012. Going forward, although there are some concerns on the KG basin gas output, we believe RIL along with BP will optimize its producing blocks in KG-D6. Moreover, the stock is currently trading at a PE of 11.1x FY2013E and 10.4x FY2014E, compared to its past five-year trading average of 17.0x forward PE. Thus, we maintain our Buy recommendation on RIL with an SOTP target price of Rs 872,” says Angel Broking research report. headline: Avoid Reliance Industries: LKP
description: Avoid Reliance Industries, says Kunal Bothra, LKP.
tags: Kunal Bothra, LKP, Reliance Industries, Stocks Views
articleBody: Avoid Reliance Industries, says Kunal Bothra, LKP. Bothra told CNBC-TV18, &quot;In Reliance Industries the overall structure is still not clear; it’s trading in a range very downside, so I would wait for a breakdown of close to Rs 700 levels to go short on this. At this point it's an avoid probably if it breaks that 200 DMA on the upside you might go long but at this point, a clear avoid.&quot; The company's trailing 12-month (TTM) EPS was at Rs 61.97 per share. (Mar, 2012). The stock's price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio was 11.94. The latest book value of the company is Rs 384.66 per share. At current value, the price-to-book value of the company was 1.92. The dividend yield of the company was 1.08%.

headline: Going ahead what is expected of RIL?
description: Reliance Industries (RIL) posted a second consecutive drop in its quarterly net profits due to a decline in refining margins and consistent fall in KG-D6 output.
tags: E&P, GRM, petchem businesses., Refining, Reliance Industries, Result Analysis
articleBody: Moneycontrol BureauReliance Industries (RIL) posted a second consecutive drop in its quarterly net profits due to a decline in refining margins and consistent fall in KG-D6 output. However, the results which were declared last Friday were in-line with street estimates with a definite surprise on the gross refining margins (GRM) front. While brokerages had estimated GRM to be below USD&amp;#36;7 per barrel, the company posted a GRM of &amp;#36;7.6 per barrel. Meanwhile, RIL is trading higher by 1.22% to Rs 740.40, after opening 1% lower at Rs 724. Going ahead, this is what brokerages expect of RIL's E&amp;amp;P, refining and petchem businesses. Exploration and production segmentBrokerages expect KG-D6 gas output to be anything between 25-30 million standard cubic feet per day (mmscmd) Analysts are also unsure of an increase in gas price for KG-D6 block from its current levels of &amp;#36;4.2 per mmbtu (million metric British thermal units) as it is fixed by an EGoM (Empowered Group of Ministers) for a period of five years. Any out-of-turn increase will invite additional&amp;nbsp; public scrutiny, especially in light of alleged inflated capex and lower-ten-approved gas production. Petchem marginsAnalyst expect petchem margins to be subdued in FY13. However, it might improve subsequently if global operating rates improve along with recovery in downstream demand. Refining marginsRefining margins will improve modestly over the next 6-9 months from current levels led by limited supply additional globally. This is what brokerages have to sayKotak Institutional SecuritiesWe do not expect meaningful improvement in RIL’s key businesses over the next 9-12 months and hence, retain our ‘reduce’ rating on the stock with a target price of Rs 770. UBSAfter pricing in negatives like weak GRMs, petchem spreads and declining KGD6 output, the firm has assigned a ‘buy’ rating on the stock with a target price of Rs 930. Goldman Sachs says its expects an upswing in refining margins and E&amp;amp;P turnaround. Hence, it has assigned a ‘buy’ rating on the stock with a target price of Rs 734.80

headline: What led RIL to post better-than-expected GRM in Q4?
description: Reliance Industries (RIL) surprised the market by posting a better-then-expected gross refining margins (GRM) at $7.6/bbl for Q4 versus $6.5 what brokerages had estimated.
articleBody: Moneycontrol Bureau Reliance Industries (RIL) surprised the market by posting a better-then-expected gross refining margins (GRMs) at &amp;#36;7.6/bbl for Q4 versus &amp;#36;6.5 what brokerages had estimated. GRM is the difference between the cost of crude and the price of refined products. This is what experts believe must have led to better GRMs for RIL SP Tulsian of sptulsian.com says: Market has not expected GRM to cross &amp;#36; 7bbl as crude cost went up. Between January and March, the price of brent crude rose 15.6% to &amp;#36;122.88 each barrel. Dealing a double blow, the rupee strengthened against the dollar by around 5%, which made crude more expensive. However,&amp;nbsp; he points out that despite better-than-expected GRM, the net profit was short of the expectation, that indicates that probably the petchem has taken more hit than what it was expected. &amp;nbsp;Energy expert Narendra Taneja believes: The sources of crude and also finding better markets where they were able to actually get better price for petroleum products such as the United States and also certain markets in the Middle East. Brokerages had estimated RIL’s GRM to come in at &amp;#36;6.5 per barrel, below the benchmark GRM of &amp;#36;7.6 per barrel. “RIL’s GRM could be 30% lower than the year ago, BoA-ML report had said. &amp;nbsp;RIL’s refinery at Jamnagar is one of the most complex plants in the world and can process heavier (impurer and cheaper) crude to yield a product slate of the same quality that other refiners produce using lighter (purer and more expensive) crude. Soaring international prices of crude lead to the price differential between light and heavy crude narrowing, since demand for the latter rises as it’s cheaper. &amp;nbsp;

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RIL's other income rises substantially in Q4: SMC Global
description: Reliance Industry quarterly results - results for the Q4 FY 12 have been in-line of the estimates.
tags: Jagannadham Thunuguntla, Q4FY12, Reliance Industries, Reliance Industry results, Result Analysis, SMC Global Securities Limited
articleBody: By Jagannadham Thunuguntla, Strategist &amp;amp; Head of Research, SMC Global Securities Limited. Reliance Industry quarterly results 1. The Reliance Industries results for the Q4FY12 have been in-line of the estimates. 2. While most of the parameters have been in-line of the estimates, there is definite positive surprise on the GRM (Gross Refining Margins). While the estimate of GRM was below US&amp;#36; 7 per barrel, the company has posted GRM of US&amp;#36; 7.6 per barrel. That’s definitely positive during this quarter. 3. One more interesting aspect of the financials is the &quot;Other Income&quot; segment. The relevance of &quot;Other Income&quot; has been substantially increasing with each passing quarter. The company has huge cash pile of about Rs 70,252 Crores. This is resulting into huge &quot;Other Income&quot; on the ample cash balances on the balance sheet of about Rs 2,295 Crores. 4. Just to put the things in perspective regarding the growing significance of &quot;Other Income&quot; in the performance of Reliance, would like to mention a quick statistic. Profit Before Tax of the company is about Rs 5,431 Crores and &quot;Other Income&quot; is about Rs 2,295 Crore. That means, about 42% of Profit Before Tax is coming from the &quot;Other Income&quot;. I can't think of any other company of the size of Reliance who gets such a massive proportion of Profit from &quot;Other Income&quot;. 5. To put in other words, the &quot;core business&quot; of the company is contributing just about 58% of the Profit Before Tax and the &quot;Other Income&quot; is contributing about 42% of the Profit Before Tax. 6. To summarize, Reliance is making more and more money out of money, less and less money out of oil. 7. Probably, it is high time that the company has to clearly pronounce the cash deployment plan regarding how are they going to use Rs 70,252 Crores. Else, this factor may remain to be huge overhang on the performance of the stock. author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Reliance Industries: Lower gas output, GRM hit FY12, net profit down 21% YoY
description: Mukesh Ambani Group's flagship company Reliance Industries's net profit fell 4.6% QoQ to Rs 4,236 crore in the quarter ended March 31, 2012 from Rs 4,440 crore in the previous quarter.
articleBody: Moneycontrol Bureau Petrochemical and oil &amp;amp; gas giant Reliance Industries’ fourth quarter net profit fell 21% year-on-year to Rs 4236 crore, weighed down by lower gas output and weak refining margins. A two-fold jump in other income and lower tax outgo helped cushion a further decline in net profit. Revenues for the quarter rose 16.7% y-o-y to Rs 87,833 crore.  The reported numbers were not much different from what the analysts community was expecting. A CNBC-TV18 poll estimated quarterly net profit at Rs 4,300 crore and revenues at Rs 84300. Oil and gas revenues fell 36.5% y-o-y, and though revenues in the refining and petrochemical segments rose 17.7% and 14% respectively, margin pressures caused operating profits to decline.&amp;nbsp;  Meanwhile, have a look at the company's segment performance during FY12, YoY Oil &amp;amp; GasNet sales Rs12898 crore versus Rs 17250 crore, down 25.2% YoYEBIT margin: 40.7% versus 36.8%, y-o-y The company said gas production from its KG-D6 basin was adversely impacted due to water/sand ingress. But going forward, the company along with its technical partner BP is working on an integrated plan to improve output from the field. Refining and marketingNet sales Rs 294736 crore versus Rs 215431 crore, YoYEBIT margin 3.3% versus 4.3%GRM &amp;#36;8.6/bbl versus &amp;#36;8.4/bbl The company processed 67.8 million tons of crude during the year and had an average utilization rate of 109% which was higher then 83.3% in North America and 76.8% in Europe. Petrochemical businessNet Sales Rs 80626 crore versus 63155 crore, YoYEBIT margins 11.1% versus 14.7%, YoYWhile the company’s polyester and Fiber intermediaries saw demand go up by 25 and 5% during the year, Polypropylene, which is largest part of RIL’s polymer portfolio saw its margins decline. RIL's market value tumbled by a third in 2011 on worries of falling output from its gas fields hurting growth. Ahead of the result announcement, shares in Reliance ended down 1.5 % to Rs 730.85,&amp;nbsp; while the Sensex fell 0.7%. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RIL vs govt row: How it reached Supreme Court
description: The cost-recovery dispute from the KG-D6 oil wells has been simmering behind closed doors between Reliance Industries and the government for nearly a year now. RIL, after ruling out any amicable settlement on the dispute has knocked the door of the Supreme Court.
tags: arbitration, Business, KG-D6, only $5.8 billion., RIL
articleBody: Moneycontrol Bureau The cost-recovery dispute from the KG-D6 oil wells has been simmering behind closed doors between Reliance Industries and the government for nearly a year now. RIL, after ruling out any amicable settlement on the dispute, has knocked the doors of the Supreme Court.  Find out what eventually led the energy giant to approach the apex court In January 2011, RIL had said it will hit peak output of 80 million standard cubic meters per day (mmscmd) from 60 mmscmd from its eastern offshore KG-DG fields in FY2012-13. But in February 2011, it issued a statement saying that&amp;nbsp;the output from KG D6 has slipped due to technical problems to about 52 mmscmd. In the same month, RIL roped in British Energy giant BP which picked up 30% stake in 23 of RIL’s oil blocks including the big gas producer D6 in the KG basin. While announcing this, RIL had said, it will use BP's technical expertise to boost output at DG block. But, even after the tie-up, output declined almost 20% month-on-month and remained pretty much stagnant in the following months. RIL expressed inability to firm up appropriate drilling locations due to geological complexities at the basin. Meanwhile, the Directorate General of Hydrocarbons (DGK) blamed RIL for drilling fewer wells as against the 31 approved under&amp;nbsp;the field development plan.&amp;nbsp;Despite RIL's repeated argument that technical glitches were leading to a decline in their&amp;nbsp;output, the DGH remained unfazed. June 2011 onwards, the blame game between the government and&amp;nbsp; RIL intensified&amp;nbsp;wherein RIL kept pointing out at excessive water/sand ingress as reasons for declining output, and the government maintained that RIL neither drilled the remaining nine oil producing wells nor took any alternative action such as revisions of the field development plan as per the provisions of the Production Sharing Contract. The PSC mentions that RIL would start sharing profits after it had recovered 100% of its drilling costs. But peeved at the way RIL was functioning, the ministry sratred moving toward restricting the 100% cost-recovery clause. Instead, it&amp;nbsp;wanted to modify the existing clause and share profits in proportion to gas output from the KG-D6 fields.  But RIL, according to reports,&amp;nbsp;communicated to the oil ministry that as per the PSC it should be allowed to recover 100% of its exploration and production costs and the government should not link cost-recovery to output. RIL argued that it had envisaged a gas output of 80 mmcmd by 2012 from an investment of &amp;#36;8.8 billion. However, it could invest only &amp;#36;5.8 billion so far and output is only about half of the desired target. To protect its interest, RIL sent an arbitration notice to the oil ministry, which the latter ignored citing it as non-event.

headline: RIL Q4 PAT seen down 32% at Rs 3657.1 cr: R K Global
description: R K Global has come out with its earnings estimates on Reliance Industries for March FY12. According to the research firm, company's Q4FY12 sales are likely to go up by 2.8% at Rs 74705.9 crore, Year-on-Year (YoY) basis.
tags: Brokerage Results Estimates, earnings estimates, net profit, R K Global, Reliance Industries, sales
articleBody: R K Global has come out with its earnings estimates on Reliance Industries for March FY12. According to the research firm, company's Q4FY12 sales are likely to go up by 2.8% at Rs 74705.9 crore, Year-on-Year (YoY) basis. The company's net profit is seen down 32% at Rs 3657.1 crore, YoY. R K Global estimates on Reliance Industries for Q4FY12: Revenue to grow 2.8% Y-o-Y We estimate RIL to post net revenue of `747059mn during Q4FY12, reporting 2.8% Y-o-Y growth. The subdued growth in revenue is attributed to production decline in its refinery segment primarily on account of 3 week maintenance shutdown of one crude distillation unit at its SEZ refinery this quarter. We expect RIL’s crude throughput to be at 15.3MMT this quarter as against 16.7MMT in Q4FY11. We see petchem volumes to be lower this quarter at 4.8MMT as against 5.2MMT. Subdued refinery and petchem margins to impact profitability Decline in Arab L-H differentials and weakness in distillate cracks will continue to put pressure on the refining margins in Asia-Pac region. We expect RIL’s refinery margin to be at USD 7.6/bbl for this quarter. While in petchem segment, margin pressure was felt in PE and PP while PVC margins saw some improvement. We expect RIL’s Operating Profit and Net Profit to decline 28.9% Y-o-Y and 32.0% Y-o-Y to Rs 76555mn and Rs 36571mn respectively.  Valuation At CMP of Rs 751.25, the stock is trading at P/E and EV/EBITDA of 8.1x and 5.6x FY13E EPS and EBITDA of Rs 93 and Rs 466790mn respectively. Key triggers to watch out for this quarter:  Refining GRM  Petchem Margins  Oil &amp;amp; Gas Output from its KG-D6 basin. We will update our target price post results and are keeping our TP of Rs 839 unchanged with high downside risk in earnings going forward. author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Worries ahead of Reliance Industries' Q4 earnings
description: Reliance Industries remains under pressure ahead of its earnings results due out on Friday. Doubts about how much natural gas can be extracted from Reliance's KG D6 blocks, and worries over its refining margins, as well as its usage of cash, have led to a string of analyst downgrades in recent weeks.
tags: Brokerage Results Estimates, earnings, KG-D6 blocks, Reliance Industries, Results, SmartEstimates, StarMine
articleBody: Reliance Industries remains under pressure ahead of its earnings results due out on Friday. Doubts about how much natural gas can be extracted from Reliance's KG D6 blocks, and worries over its refining margins, as well as its usage of cash, have led to a string of analyst downgrades in recent weeks. Top-ranked analysts from StarMine are much more pessimistic about Reliance's upcoming earnings, forecasting a fiscal fourth quarter net profit of Rs 4,258 crore, nearly 7% below the wider consensus forecasts. Operating profits are seen at Rs 6,897 crore by this select group, 2.7% below consensus estimates, according to StarMine's SmartEstimates. Shares of Reliance Industries were down 0.3% in afternoon trading. Shares have fallen about 8.5% since the beginning of March, compared with a 3.3% fall in the broader Nifty index.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Siemens may look at specific projects with RIL
description: India's Siemens Ltd may partner with energy-led conglomerate Reliance Industries Ltd for future security solution projects on a case-by-case basis, a senior official said, after the two companies declined to bid for an ambitious Mumbai project.
tags: Business, mumbai, Reliance Industries Ltd, Siemens Ltd
articleBody: India's Siemens Ltd may partner with energy-led conglomerate Reliance Industries Ltd for future security solution projects on a case-by-case basis, a senior official said, after the two companies declined to bid for an ambitious Mumbai project. The two companies did not bid for a security project for the city of Mumbai, either individually or jointly, after declaring their intent in September to join hands together for developing homeland security applications for the Indian market. &quot;for economic reasons we refrained from submitting the bid,&quot; said Tilak Raj Seth, executive vice president for infrastructure and cities sector at Siemens India. On April 4, Business Standard reported that the venture between the two companies may come to an end owing to differences over strategic and operational issues. &quot;There was no JV (joint venture). We offered in a consortium and this is now gone, because the bid is gone,&quot; said Armin Bruck, managing director, Siemens Ltd. He said that the two companies may bid for projects in future if their product portfolios matched. &quot;Only time will show. If our portfolio is the right mix, then why not?&quot; said Bruck.

headline: RIL's Q4 PAT seen down 24% at Rs 4092.3 cr: MOST
description: Motilal Oswal has come out with its earnings estimates on Reliance Industries for March quarter FY12. According to the research firm, the company's Q4FY12 sales are likely to go up by 28.5% at Rs 93400 crore, Year-on-Year (YoY) basis.
tags: Brokerage Results Estimates, earnings estimates, March quarter, Motilal Oswal, Profit, Reliance Industries, RIL, sales
articleBody: Motilal Oswal has come out with its earnings estimates on&amp;nbsp;Reliance Industries&amp;nbsp;for March quarter FY12. According to the research firm, the company's Q4FY12 sales are likely to go up by 28.5% at Rs 93400 crore, Year-on-Year (YoY) basis. The company's net profit is seen down 23.9% at Rs 4092.3 crore, YoY. Motilal Oswal's estimates on&amp;nbsp;Reliance Industries&amp;nbsp;Q4 results: We expect RIL to report a GRM of USD6.5/bbl v/s USD6.8/bbl in 3QFY12. Petchem EBIT is estimated to be lower QoQ led by sharp decline in margins and flat volumes. We expect average KG-D6 volumes in 4QFY12 at 35mmscmd v/s 41mmscmd in 3QFY12. We expect RIL to report net profit of INR40.9b (v/s INR53.8b in 4QFY11 and INR44.4b in 3QFY12). The subdued performance would be on account of lower refining and petchem margins, and continuous decline in gas production from the KG-D6 basin, which would partially get offset by higher other income. Key things to watch out for: (1) GRM, (2) petchem margin, and (3) KG-D6 production. The stock trades at 10.8x FY13E adjusted EPS of INR66.9. We maintain Neutral due to concerns on cash utilization, RoE reaching sub 15% levels and increased share (80%) of cyclical refining and petchem businesses to the earnings. headline: RIL Q4 PAT seen down 22.3% at Rs 4177 cr: Angel Broking
description: Angel Broking has come out with its earnings estimates on Reliance Industries for March FY12. According to the research firm, company's Q4FY12 sales are likely to go up by 16.5% at Rs 84669 crore, Year-on-Year (YoY) basis.
tags: Angel Broking, Brokerage Results Estimates, earnings estimates, net profit, Reliance Industries, sales
articleBody: Angel Broking has come out with its earnings estimates on Reliance Industries for March quarter FY12. According to the research firm, company's Q4FY12 sales are likely to go up by 16.5% at Rs 84669 crore, Year-on-Year (YoY) basis on the back of higher prices of petrochemical products. However, the company's net profit is seen down 22.3% at Rs 4177 crore, YoY, mainly due to lower gas production from KG-D6 block. Angel Broking estimates on Reliance Industries for Q4FY12: RIL's KG-D6 output hits all-time low  Reliance Industries' (RIL) largest gas fields in the KG-D6 gas block have hit an all-time low production of 28mmscmd as the firm shut six wells due to water and sand ingress. Dhirubhai 1 and 3 gas fields in the eastern offshore KG-DWN-98/3 output plummeted to 28mmscmd during the week ending March 4, 2012. Including the gas production of 6.5mmscmd from MA fields, total production from KG-D6 block averaged 35mmscmd (significantly below the field development plan of 70 mmscmd approved during 2006) during the same week. We continue to await further clarity on the sustainable levels of production from KG-D6 block. author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Oil &amp; Gas sector results preview for Q4FY12: PLilladher
description: Prabhudas Lilladher has come with its March quarterly earning estimates for Oil &amp; Gas sector. As per the research firm, Crude oil witnessed significant increase during the quarter, with Brent oil prices increasing to an average of US$118.5/bbl, with prices ranging between US$108- 126/bbl.
tags: Brokerage Results Estimates, Cairn India, GAIL, Gujarat Gas Company, Gujarat State Petronet, Indraprastha Gas, oil & gas sector, Oil & Natural Gas Corporation, Oil India, Petronet LNG, Prabhudas Lilladher, Reliance Industries
articleBody: Prabhudas Lilladher has come with its March quarterly earning estimates for Oil &amp;amp; Gas sector. As per the research firm, Crude oil witnessed significant increase during the quarter, with Brent oil prices increasing to an average of US&amp;#36;118.5/bbl, with prices ranging between US&amp;#36;108- 126/bbl. Crude oil saw a signficant increase during the quarter, with Brent oil prices averaging at US&amp;#36;118.5/bbl. Prices were high on account of geopolitical tension building between Iran and Western countries. GRMs witnessed marginal contraction on account of weakness in the distillates cracks. In the Petchem segment, global cracker margins improved, while the pressure was felt in PE and PP margins. The PVC margins witnessed an improvement.  Crude oil witnessed significant increase during the quarter, with Brent oil prices increasing to an average of US&amp;#36;118.5/bbl, with prices ranging between US&amp;#36;108- 126/bbl. The main drivers of the oil prices were supply-led concerns, led by Iran-EU tension over oil sanction and Sudan-South Sudan dispute over transit fees. EU has banned Iranian crude imports at the end of January 2012 and gave six months grace period for the EU members to end oil contract by July 1. In response, Iran warned to close the Strait of Hormuz, the main crude shipping lanes and prepared to stop oil exports to the EU immediately. The action has tightened crude oil market as the EU usually imports crude from Iran at around 400-500 thousand barrels per day. Light-heavy differentials declined on a QoQ basis, with AH-AL spread averaging at US&amp;#36;3.3/bbl as against US&amp;#36;3.9/bbl. The spreads between Dubai Fateh-AH declined to US&amp;#36;(0.7)/bbl as against US&amp;#36;0.5/bbl in the previous quarter. The same is likely to adversely impact the performance of RIL as the premium over the Singapore GRMS is likely to further decline in the current quarter as RIL procures heavy grade of the crude with API similar to Arab Heavy crude. author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RIL, BP submit revised field development plan
description: With KG-D6 output hitting an all- time low, Reliance Industries and its British partner BP plc have submitted to the government a revised field development plan for enhancing gas production from MA field in the block.
articleBody: With KG-D6 output hitting an all- time low, Reliance Industries and its British partner BP plc have submitted to the government a revised field development plan for enhancing gas production from MA field in the block. RIL-BP propose to drill one gas production well on the MA oilfield in the eastern offshore KG-DWN-98/3 or KG-D6 block besides intervention jobs in at least two of the existing six wells on the fields, sources privy to the development said. MA is the only oil find made by RIL in the 7,645 square kilometre KG-D6 block. The field produces about 11,200 barrels a day of along and associated gas of 6.45 million cubic meters per day. MA field makes up for about one-fifth of the 34.09 mmcmd of current gas output from KG-D6 block. Sources said six wells had been drilled on MA field, of which one had to be closed because of water loading and sand ingress. RIL-BP plan to do workover (intervention activity involving invasive techniques to raise output) on the closed well and at least one more well facing similar problems. This together with a seventh well, which would only produce gas unlike the current five wells that produce both oil and gas, would help the field raise output to 8 mmcmd. MA field had begun oil production in September 2008 and gas in April 2009 and in 2010 had averaged 8 mmcmd of gas output. Sources said the revised FDP for MA field was submitted to the Directorate General of Hydrocarbons (DGH) in February and RIL-BP have made technical presentation.  Also, RIL-BP are working on an integrated and capital efficient plan for block development, involving production from all the 18 gas discoveries in KG-D6. They projected first gas from R-Series, the third largest gas find in KG-D6 block, by 2015 and production from satellite fields by 2016 subject to timely regulatory approvals. RIL began production from Dhirubhai-1 and 3 (D1&amp;amp;D3) fields, the largest among the 18 gas and one oil find, in April 2009 but output has fallen from a peak of 54 million cubic meters per day in March 2010 to 27.64 mmcmd this month. Together with 6.45 mmcmd of gas production from D-26 or MA oil field in the same area, block output is 34.09 mmcmd. The plan would help in cost savings of over USD 1 billion due to integration and optimisation. In addition, un-incurred phase-II cost of D1&amp;amp;D3 field development plan (USD 3.1 billion out of total cost of USD 8.8 billion) would not be required to be spent, they said. Sources said RIL-BP plan to connect R-Series and four satellite fields, for which a USD 1.529 billion field development plan was approved by the government in January, to the existing infrastructure used to produce gas from D1&amp;amp;D3 and MA. Also, other satellite fields would be hooked up to these. R-series and four satellite fields alone have potential to add 30 mmscmd of output.&amp;nbsp;

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'Rakesh Patil'}
headline: Expect new lows in Reliance Industries: Jai Bala
description: Expect new lows in Reliance Industries, says Jai Bala of cashthechaos.com.
tags: Jai Bala of Cashthechaos.com, Reliance Industries, Stocks Views
articleBody: Expect new lows in Reliance Industries, says Jai Bala of cashthechaos.com. Bala told CNBC-TV18, &quot;I am expecting new lows on Reliance. I am sure most of the technicians are expecting that. I have been expecting this for quite some weeks. I told you that the day before I was here for the Budget, the stock had clocked, overlapped the initial high it made from the December lows. That tells us that the move from the December lows is actually a corrective price action, not a new uptrend. So if I were to quantify levels to which Reliance can reach, I think it is going to go to a minimum of Rs 640.&quot; The company's trailing 12-month (TTM) EPS was at Rs 61.97 per share. (Dec, 2011). The stock's price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio was 11.75. The latest book value of the company is Rs 384.66 per share. At current value, the price-to-book value of the company was 1.89. The dividend yield of the company was 1.1%.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Reliance Industries down on E&amp;P worries
description: Shares in Reliance Industries were hit by concerns about its exploration and production (E&amp;P) business, primarily due to continued regulatory uncertainty over the development of its KG-D6 block.
tags: Business, KG-D6 block, LNG, Reliance Industries
articleBody: Shares in Reliance Industries were hit by concerns about its exploration and production (E&amp;amp;P) business, primarily due to continued regulatory uncertainty over the development of its KG-D6 block. Output from KG-D6 has been declining for more than a year, resulting in a sharp fall in India's gas output and forcing the country to resort to increased imports of expensive liquefied natural gas (LNG). Reliance Industries fell 1.5% in afternoon trade. The stock has lost 9.4% in March as of Friday's close, compared with a 2% fall in India's 50-share Index Nifty in the equivalent period.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RIL's KG-D6 gas fields may hold lower reserves: Niko
description: Reliance Industries' offshore KG-D6 fields may hold lower than previously anticipated natural gas reserves, the company's minority partner Niko Resources said today.
tags: Business, KG-D6, KG-D6 block, Niko Resources, Reliance Industries
articleBody: Reliance Industries' offshore KG-D6 fields may hold lower than previously anticipated natural gas reserves, the company's minority partner Niko Resources said today. The Canadian firm in a statement said it expects a drop in reserves at Dhirubhai-1 and 3 (D1 &amp;amp; D3), the largest of the 18 gas finds in KG-D6 block. &quot;Production performance at the D1/D3 fields within the D6 block indicates the need for a revision to the current geological model. While analysis continues, Niko anticipates a drop in its reserves for the D1/D3 fields,&quot; the company said without giving details. D1 &amp;amp; D3 had previously been stated to hold about 11 Trillion cubic feet of gas reserves. Niko, which holds 10% stake in the RIL-operated KG-DWN-98/3 or KG-D6 block off the Andhra coast, had last month stated that gas production in the October-December quarter from the D6 block averaged 40.49 million cubic meters per day, as compared to 55.21 mmcmd in the year-ago period. D6 gas production in December averaged approximately 137 mmcfd (38.79 mmcmd for the entire block), Niko had said. &quot;Declines are expected to continue until workovers are completed and/or additional wells are tied in,&quot; it had added. The current output is less than half of the peak 80 mmcmd that RIL had projected as fewer wells were drilled than planned and seven wells ceased to produce due to the entry of sand or water. RIL has so far drilled 22 wells on D1&amp;amp;D3 but only 18 were put on production. Of these, six have ceased due to water/sand ingress. The company is to do workovers or maintenance of these well, which may raise the output, Niko said. MA oilfield in the same block had seen one out of the five wells cease due to the same reasons. The Canadian firm today said plans were approved for the development of the first four satellite discoveries around the currently producing D1&amp;amp;D3. Besides sizeable production would come when R-Series fields in the block are developed. &quot;On the positive side, as development plans are approved, Niko contemplates additional reserves from the R complex, satellite fields and full block development,&quot; Niko said.&amp;nbsp; These fields can add up to 30 mmcmd to the output. RIL holds 60% interest in the 7,645-sq-km D6 block after farming-out 30% stake in BP Plc of UK. Production of oil from the MA discovery began in September 2008 and production of gas from the Dhirubhai 1 and 3 (D1 &amp;amp; D3) discoveries in April 2009. The Company has been granted petroleum mining licences for the discoveries expiring in 2028 and 2025, respectively.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Economic Survey: Gas output from RIL's KG-D6 fields falls 22% in FY12
description: Reliance Industries' KG-D6 fields have seen nearly 22% fall in production this fiscal due to drop in pressure and water ingress in wells, finance ministry-prepared Economic Survey said today.
tags: Business, Economic Survey, KG-D6, Reliance Industries
articleBody: Reliance Industries' KG-D6 fields have seen nearly 22% fall in production this fiscal due to drop in pressure and water ingress in wells, finance ministry-prepared Economic Survey said today. The pre-Budget policy document said gas production from KG-D6 fields during April-December 2011-12 was about 12.36 billion cubic meters against the production of 15.82 BCM during the same period in 2010-11. &quot;The gas production has reportedly decreased due to drop in pressure in the wells and increased water ingress leading to lower output of gas per well,&quot; it said. Drop in KG-D6 production pulled down nation's gas output during first nine months of the current fiscal to 36.19 BCM as compared to 39.68 BCM during the same period last year. &quot;The projected production for natural gas, including coal bed methane (CBM) for 2011-12 is 51.67 (BCM), which is 1.05% lower than the actual production of 52.22 BCM in 2010-11,&quot; it said. During the current fiscal, production of crude oil is estimated at 38.19 million tonnes, which is about 1.33% higher than the 37.70 million tonnes produced during 2010-11. Domestic crude oil production during April-December was 28.70 million tonnes showing a growth of 1.9% over the same period of the previous year. Oil production from Cairn India's prolific Rajasthan block was 4.80 million tonnes in nine months of current fiscal against total production of 5.148 million tons during full 2010-11 fiscal. The Survey said a total of USD 15.88 billion investment has been made in 235 blocks awarded in eight auction rounds under New Exploration Licensing Policy (NELP) since 1999. &quot;Under NELP 103 oil and gas discoveries have been made by private/joint venture (JV) companies in 34 blocks and more than 600 million tonnes of oil equivalent hydrocarbon reserves have been added,&quot; it said. India has the fourth largest proven coal reserves in the world and holds significant prospects for exploration and exploitation of CBM. Under the CBM policy, 33 exploration blocks, the Survey said, adding 8.92 Trillion cubic feet output of prognosticated resources of about 92 Tcf, have sofar been established. &quot;Commercial production of CBM in India has now become a reality with current CBM gas production of about 0.23 million cubic metre per day,&quot; it said.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;  The document said shale gas can emerge as an important new source of energy in the country. Shale gas resources are spread over several sedimentary basins such as Cambay, Gondwana, Krishna-Godawari, and Cauvery.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Niko sees lower reserves at D6 block in India
description: Canadian oil and gas producer Niko Resources Ltd expects lower natural gas reserves at the D6 block located off India's east coast, and said the area's geological model may need to be revised.
tags: Business, Niko Resources Ltd, Reliance Industries
articleBody: Canadian oil and gas producer Niko Resources Ltd expects lower natural gas reserves at the D6 block located off India's east coast, and said the area's geological model may need to be revised. In February, the company reported a quarterly loss on lower production from the D6 block and said the output decline could continue at the site. On Thursday, Niko said it expects a drop in its reserves at the D1-D3 fields within the D6 block. The D6 block, which is majority owned by Reliance Industries, contributed 79% to Niko's total production last year. Natural gas production at the block has been declining as fewer wells were drilled than planned and some wells ceased to produce due to the entry of sand or water. Niko's shares, which have lost 12% of their value in the last six months, closed at C&amp;#36; 46.20 on Wednesday on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Panel approved less than half of RIL's expenditure on KG-D6
description: A government-controlled oversight panel has so far approved less than half of the USD 9.47 billion expenditure that Reliance Industries has claimed for producing oil and gas from its KG-D6 block.
tags: Business, CAG, KG-D6 block, oil&gas, production sharing contract, Reliance Industries, S Jaipal Reddy
articleBody: A government-controlled oversight panel has so far approved less than half of the USD 9.47 billion expenditure that Reliance Industries has claimed for producing oil and gas from its KG-D6 block, Oil Minister S Jaipal Reddy said today. The contract for eastern offshore KG-DWN-98/3 or KG-D6 block provides for all actual expenditure incurred to be first recovered from sale of oil/gas before profits are split between the contractor and the government. Reddy said RIL has claimed USD 9.47 billion in cost of developing Dhirubhai-1 and 3 (D1&amp;amp;D3) gas fields, MA oilfield and exploration in the 7,645 sq km block in Bay of Bengal. Of this, it has recovered USD 5.26 billion even though the Management Committee, which overseas operations of the block, has approved only USD 3.99 billion cost recovery up to 2007-08 fiscal. &quot;While contractor (RIL) has claimed an expenditure of USD 9.47 billion and cost recovered USD 5.26 billion up to 2010-11, the MC has approved only USD 3.99 billion up to financial year 2007-08,&quot; he said in a written reply to a question in Rajya Sabha. Of the USD 9.47 billion, RIL and its partners had incurred USD 5.7 billion in developing D1&amp;amp;D3 gas fields and another USD 1.73 billion in bringing MA oilfield into production. &quot;The audited accounts are placed before MC for adopting the same as provided under the Production Sharing Contract (PSC). MC has approved the said audited accounts upto the year 2007-08,&quot; he added without details of accounts of subsequent years. The auditors appointed by the Government had audited accounts of KG-D6 block up to 2006-07. The Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) carried out a special audit of the block for 2006-07 and 2007-08 and has agreed to conduct regular audit for the block for 2008-09. Reddy said while CAG in report had observed that large procurement contracts were given on single bid basis, the top auditor &quot;has not quantified any loss of revenue to the Government.&quot; &quot;The report of the CAG is under consideration of Public Accounts Committee (PAC),&quot; he added.&amp;nbsp; Natural gas production at KG-D6 has fallen to about 35-36 million standard cubic meters per day from 61.5 mmscmd achieved in March 2010. While RIL says output has fallen because of fall in reservior pressure and ingress of water and sand in wells, the oil ministry and its technical arm Directorate General of Hydrocarbons (DGH) believes it is due to the company drilling less number of wells.  &quot;DGH under this ministry has reported that the reasons for lower gas production from D1&amp;amp;D3 fields in the block KG-DWN-98/3 may be attributed to drilling of less number of development wells (producers) as compared to that envisaged in the MC approved Addendum to Initial Development Plan,&quot; Minister of State for Petroleum and Natural Gas R P N Singhsaid in reply to a separate question.  In addition, six out of 18 producing wells in D1&amp;amp;D3 fields have ceased to produce gas due to water loading/sand ingress, he said. In case of MA field in the same block, one oil/gas producing well out of six oil/gas producing wells has also ceased due to water loading in the well, he said.&amp;nbsp; &quot;As per approved AIDP, contractor is required to drill, complete and put on production total 22 wells by March 2011 and 31 wells by March 2012. &quot;The contractor has, however, drilled total 22 wells so far, out of which 18 wells were put on production. Balance four wells are to be completed or connected for production,&quot; he added. RIL, he said, has been asked to &quot;increase the gas production from D1&amp;amp;D3 fields by adopting appropriate measures such as well drilling, well intervention etc.&quot;

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: CAG finds faults in KG-D6 contract awarded to RIL: Sources
description: The Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) has found deficiencies in the KG-D6 contract that was awarded to Reliance Industries in 2001, CNBC-TV18 has learnt.
tags: Bay of Bengal, Business, Comptroller and Auditor General, oil ministry
articleBody: The Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) has found deficiencies in the KG-D6 contract that was awarded to Reliance Industries in 2001, CNBC-TV18 has learnt. The CAG faulted the Oil Ministry and its technical arm, the Directorate General of Hydrocarbons (DGH), for allowing RIL to retain the entire 7,645 sq km KG-DWN-98/3 (KG-D6) block in the Bay of Bengal after the giant Dhirubhai-1 and 3 gas finds were made in 2001 because-- as per the PSC, RIL should have relinquished 25% of the total area outside the discoveries in June, 2004, and 2005, but the entire block was declared as a discovery area and the company was allowed to retain it. However, CAG has handed over the matter to Public Accounts Committee (PAC) which is scrutinising the findings CAG on the KG-D6 gas block.  &amp;nbsp;

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RIL keen on Cairn crude for Jamnagar SEZ refinery
description: Reliance Industries wants to buy Cairn India's Rajasthan crude oil for processing at its only- for-exports Jamnagar refinery in Gujarat and has approached the government for its approval nod for the same.
tags: Business, Cairn India, Jamnagar refinery, Rajasthan crude oil, Reliance Industries
articleBody: Reliance Industries wants to buy Cairn India's Rajasthan crude oil for processing at its only- for-exports Jamnagar refinery in Gujarat and has approached the government for its approval nod for the same. RIL currently buys 80,000 barrels per day (bpd) or 4 million tonnes a year crude from Rajasthan, that it processes at its old 33 million tonnes a year domestic tariff area (DTA) refinery on the West Coast. It has now applied to the government to buy another 30,000 bpd of Cairn crude for turning it into fuel at its 29 million tonnes SEZ (Special Economic Zone) refinery adjacent to the old unit. Official sources said the company's request would be considered by the Board of Approval, headed by Commerce Secretary Rahul Khullar, next week. Any sale to a SEZ or only-for-exports unit is considered outward shipment or exports out of India. The current policy does not allow export of domestically produced crude oil. RIL's request comes just when Cairn is beginning to ramp up production from Rajasthan fields. Cairn currently produces 125,000 barrels per day from Mangala oilfield, the largest find in the Rajasthan block. Another 20,000 bpd is produced from Bhagyam fields. Mangala can go up to 150,000 bpd or 7.5 million tonnes a year anytime now while Bhagyam has an approved peak of 40,000 bpd and can go up to 60,000 bpd with more investments. Sources said Cairn currently sells 15,000-20,000 bpd to state-owned Indian Oil Corp (IOC) and another 30,000-40,000 bpd to Essar Oil. RIL's refinery complex at Jamnagar, consisting of the old DTA refinery and an SEZ unit, are connected by a heated pipeline to the Mangala field in Rajasthan. Rajasthan crude is very heavy with API (American Petroleum Institute) gravity between 25-30. Also, waxiness of the crude turns it into solid at room temperature. Transportation of the Rajasthan crude therefore, requires special heating arrangements in the pipeline to keep the crudein a liquid form. Most Indian domestic refineries lack the configuration to process Rajasthan crude due to its quality. Others face logistical issues. Sources said RIL's SEZ refinery, which is designed to process far heavier crudes, is unable to use Rajasthan crude as the same has been classified as a restricted item under the current Foreign Trade Policy (FTP) provisions. The unit has, therefore, sought approval of the BoA for the importing crude oil from Cairn India.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Oil Min to seek Law Min's opinion on RIL demand
description: The Oil Ministry is likely to refer Reliance Industries' demand for an increase in price of natural gas it produces from eastern offshore KG-D6 fields to the Law Ministry.
tags: Business, KG-D6, oil ministry, Reliance Industries
articleBody: The Oil Ministry is likely to refer Reliance Industries' demand for an increase in price of natural gas it produces from eastern offshore KG-D6 fields to the Law Ministry. &quot;We will take an opinion of the Law Ministry before proceeding on the issue,&quot; an Oil Ministry official said here. RIL had on January 6 written to the Oil Ministry and the Prime Minister's Office (PMO) seeking a gas price revision, saying the current USD 4.2 per million British thermal unit rate for KG-D6 gas was &quot;sub-market&quot; price compared with three times higher price being paid for imported gas (LNG). The PMO subsequently asked the oil ministry to legally examine if the government can allow RIL to increase the price. The government had in 2007 fixed USD 4.20 per mmBtu as the price of gas produced from KG-D6 fields for first five years of production. KG-D6 fields started production in 2009. But the Oil Ministry's letter on October 10, 2007, informing RIL of the pricing decision did not stop at this and went on to state that if the company was to realise a price higher than USD 4.20 per mmBtu, then that rate would be used for determining government's take from KG-D6 block. Sources said it is perplexing why this clause was inserted if the gas price was to be USD 4.2 per mmBtu for five years as the Oil Ministry is insisting now. RIL had originally proposed a rate of over USD 4.3 per mmBtu for first three years of production which was later tweeked by an Empowered Group of Ministers (EGoM) to USD 4.2 per mmBtu for five years. &quot;If the actual price at which any supplies made to any consumer happens to be higher than the one arrived at by (the formula approved by the EGoM), then the higher price shall be taken for purposes of the Government take for that quantity,&quot; the ministry wrote to RIL on October 10, 2007. This clause in the oil ministry letter may be the reason behind RIL's January 6 letter seeking revision of &quot;discriminatory&quot; and &quot;sub-market&quot; price for KG-D6. Sources said the ministry is not inclined to accept RIL request on the grounds that RIL had accepted to keep price stable at USD 4.2 per mmBtu for five years. It is also relying on the Supreme Court's May 7, 2010 judgement in the gas row between RIL and Anil Ambani's RNRL that stated that government alone has the right to fix the selling price of gas from all fields including KG-D6. When the nation can pay USD 12-14 per mmBtu price to overseas producers of liquefied natural gas (LNG), the domestic gas producers too deserve an equivalent price. While high imported LNG price gives no incentive to the government, a higher domestic price would fetch it higher revenues in form of royalty, taxes and profit petroleum.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RIL buys 3.73% for Rs 192 cr, hikes stake in EIH to 18.53%
description: Mukesh Ambani-led Reliance Industries increased its stake in hospitality firm EIH to 18.53% by picking additional 2.13 crore shares worth Rs 192 crore through an open market transaction.
articleBody: Mukesh Ambani-led Reliance Industries increased its stake in hospitality firm EIH to 18.53% by picking additional 2.13 crore shares worth Rs 192 crore through an open market transaction. RIL subsidiary Reliance Industries Investment and Holding Pvt Ltd purchased 21,315,000 shares of EIH (accounting for 3.73% stake) for Rs 90 apiece valuing the deal to Rs 191.83 crore, according to information available with the stock exchanges. As of December quarter, Reliance Industries Investment and Holding Pvt Ltd held 84,592,273 shares or 14.8% stake in EIH. Meanwhile, two promoters -- Gaylord Impex and Pivet Finances of EIH Ltd have exited the company by offloading their entire stake. Gaylord Impex sold 88,19,683 shares of the company, while Pivet Finances 1,24,82,720 offloaded equities in the hospitality firm. The shares were sold at Rs 90 apiece. In September 2010, RIL had acquired a 14.12% stake in EIH, which operates hotels and resorts under the Oberoi and Trident brands, for Rs 1,021 crore at a premium of 22% per share. Shares of Reliance Industries closed 0.49% higher at Rs 814.35 apiece on the BSE, while EIH's stock rose by 2.05% to end at Rs 89.70 on the bourse.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: BP, RIL to submit KG block development plan soon
description: Reliance Industries and joint venture partner BP Plc will submit a single development plan for the entire KG D6 oil and gas block to the government in a few weeks, the head of BP's Indian unit said.
articleBody: Reliance Industries and joint venture partner BP Plc will submit a single development plan for the entire KG D6 oil and gas block to the government in a few weeks, the head of BP's Indian unit said. The D6 gas output has been declining for more than a year, resulting in a sharp fall in India's gas output and forcing the country to resort to increased imports of expensive liquefied natural gas (LNG) to meet demands of its expanding economy. Gas output, currently around 37-38 million standard cubic meters a day (mscmd), may average 27.60 mscmd in the fiscal year starting April, about 66% lower than initially estimated, a government source said earlier this month. &quot;It will maximise use of the entire existing infrastructure to produce the balance of the discoveries and minimize new infrastructure needed,&quot; BP India head Sashi Mukundan told reporters. A single development plan for the entire KG D6 block, compared to current norm of field-wise plans, will bring more certainty and comfort to customers, he said. BP acquired stake in 23 oil and gas blocks in India, some in the KG block, from Reliance Industries in a USD 7.2 billion deal last year. The two companies aim to boost production to a sustainable level from both the existing fields and the next wave of developments -- D6 satellites &amp;amp; R Series and the NEC-25. Reliance, India's biggest company by market value, has been under pressure from the government and investors because of the falling gas output, and its market value tumbled 35% in 2011, underperforming the main Mumbai market. Earlier, Mukundan said the British oil and gas major wanted a predictable pricing regime for natural gas in India, as this is vital for developing future projects in the country. &quot;Clarity on gas pricing is vital for the development of the 'next wave' of projects, which will add production beyond 2015 but for which investment decisions need to be made now,&quot; he said at an event. Gas prices in India are set between USD 4 to USD 6 per million British thermal units (MBTU) but are far below double-digit prices globally, in part to be competitive with cheap local coal. Reliance shares closed down 4.7% at Rs 781.45&amp;nbsp;in a Mumbai market that fell 2.7%.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Reliance Brands, Iconix form JV
description: Reliance Brands, part of Mukesh Ambani's Reliance Industries, has partnered with Iconix Brand Group to sell the US company's fashion and home brands in India.
tags: Business, Iconix Brand Group, Mukesh Ambani, Reliance Brands, Reliance Industries
articleBody: Reliance Brands, part of Mukesh Ambani's Reliance Industries, has partnered with Iconix Brand Group to sell the US company's fashion and home brands in India. The joint venture will offer Iconix brands such as London Fog, Ed Hardy, Mossimo and Ocean Pacific in India. The Times of India newspaper reported earlier on Wednesday that the companies signed an equal joint venture for 20 of Iconix's lifestyle brands, which it said generated total global revenue of USD 12 billion. Financial details of the deal were not available. &quot;We are on our way to achieving our long-term goal of growing international revenue to a third of our total business,&quot; Iconix Chairman Neil Cole said in a statement. Reliance Brands will hold a 50% stake in Iconix India, a unit of the US company, the Times report said. Reliance Brands' chief executive, Darshan Mehta, was quoted in the report as saying that it had paid a &quot;significant upfront amount&quot; to buy the stake and the rights.
